title: ‘The Sound of Silence’ Review: Good—and Bad—Vibrations
text:
Art is supposed to help us see the world in novel ways. “The Sound of Silence,” in its quietly exhilarating manner, may make us hear it differently, too.

Based on his short film “Palimpsest,” Michael Tyburski ’s debut feature has at its center what Hitchcock might have called a MacGuffin—the thing the movie’s not really about. Peter Lucian ( Peter Sarsgaard ) is a “house tuner,” a profession he’s invented and practices around New York, for a strictly word-of-mouth clientele. Armed with tuning forks and a classical-music education, he takes readings in the homes of unhappy apartment dwellers, determines what chord the place is playing—no one wants a diminished life caused by a diminished chord—and adjusts accordingly. Feng shui for the ears.

“Your radiator is D-flat,” he tells one satisfied customer. Of Ellen ( Rashida Jones ), a transplant from Ohio living alone in one of the noisiest cities in the world, he asks, “Do you eat bagels every morning?” She needs a new toaster. The old one has put her apartment, and her life, in a minor key. C-minor, to be precise.

It’s a fascinating device, largely because Mr. Tyburski, who co-wrote the screenplay (and “Palimpsest”) with Ben Nabors, is no more of a rush to explain things than is Peter Lucian. Mr. Sarsgaard gives a measured and characteristically nuanced performance as a man absorbed in his work to a degree that is perhaps not healthy, but is for him both real and rewarding. And the stuff of obsession. His failure to pick up the clues Ellen drops, that she’s interested in more than his acoustics, tells us much about Peter. And Mr. Tyburski’s small directorial moves tell us much about her: “May I lie down on your bed?” Peter asks Ellen, who blanches, but agrees; Peter wants to mimic her morning routine as closely as possible, which includes reaching an arm across the bed and finding no one there.

Peter Sarsgaard Photo: IFC Films

Comparisons have already been made between Mr. Tyburski’s film and those of Michael Almereyda (“Marjorie Prime,” “Hamlet”), with their coolly intellectual surfaces and subsurface passion. “The Conversation” is also an unavoidable reference. But I kept thinking of Amir Naderi, the great Iranian émigré director whose films about New York (“Manhattan by Numbers,” “ABC Manhattan,” “Marathon”) not only captured an oft-filmed city in exciting new ways but examined the many different worlds that coexist within it, independent and unknowing of each other. In Mr. Tyburski’s drama, one of those worlds is the professional study of sound and one of Peter’s crises is his rejection by academia: His supposed mentor ( Austin Pendleton ) betrays him, and he’s brutally brushed off by the editor of a prestigious journal on sound, to which he’s submitted a paper on his theory that human behavior is determined by subliminal tones—Central Park is in G; Wall Street is B-minor; the Lower East Side is A-flat. Most of what we regard as noise—except that defined as white noise—actually possesses a tone. Peter has found one on each block of the city.

Ellen rejects Peter’s theory, which she regards as a kind of predestination. They talk at cross purposes. Is anyone listening? Not when they should be, it seems: During their initial meeting, Peter asks Ellen, “Do you walk to work?”—to which she responds by telling him how satisfying she finds her job. It’s not deafness, exactly. Peter’s “home tuning” is about addressing the sound people don’t even know they’re listening to, and can’t help hearing. But they don’t listen to each other, either, and a new toaster won’t fix that.

—Mr. Anderson is a Journal TV critic. Joe Morgenstern is on vacation.
description: A ‘house tuner’ divines the musical chords of different locales, what they mean for the people who inhabit them, in Michael Tyburski’s debut feature.
